title: 1 Corinthians Chapter 4 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on 1 Corinthians chapter 4 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: 1 Corinthians Chapter 4 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of 1 Corinthians Chapter 4.

questions.question: According to 1 Corinthians 4:1, how should a man regard Paul and his companions?
options: As ministers of Christ and stewards of the mysteries of God
questions.correctAnswer: As ministers of Christ and stewards of the mysteries of God
questions.explanation: 1 Corinthians 4:1 states that men should account Paul and his companions as ministers of Christ and stewards of the mysteries of God.

questions.question: What is required of stewards according to 1 Corinthians 4:2?
options: That a man be found faithful
questions.correctAnswer: That a man be found faithful
questions.explanation: 1 Corinthians 4:2 explains that it is required of stewards that they be found faithful.

questions.question: Who judges Paul according to 1 Corinthians 4:4?
questions.correctAnswer: The Lord
questions.explanation: 1 Corinthians 4:4 states that Paul does not judge himself, but the one who judges him is the Lord.

questions.question: In 1 Corinthians 4:5, when should men not judge anything?
options: Before the time, until the Lord comes
questions.correctAnswer: Before the time, until the Lord comes
questions.explanation: 1 Corinthians 4:5 advises not to judge anything before the time, until the Lord comes and reveals hidden things.

questions.question: According to 1 Corinthians 4:7, why should no one glory as if they had not received what they have?
options: Because everything they have was received
Because they are better than others
Because they are chosen by God
questions.correctAnswer: Because everything they have was received
questions.explanation: 1 Corinthians 4:7 teaches that no one should glory as if they had not received what they have, since all things are received.

questions.question: What does Paul say the apostles were made a spectacle unto, in 1 Corinthians 4:9?
questions.correctAnswer: The world, angels, and men
questions.explanation: 1 Corinthians 4:9 states that the apostles were made a spectacle unto the world, angels, and men.

questions.question: Which of the following hardships does Paul mention in 1 Corinthians 4:11?
questions.correctAnswer: Hunger, thirst, nakedness, and buffeting
questions.explanation: 1 Corinthians 4:11 lists hunger, thirst, nakedness, and buffeting as hardships Paul and his companions faced.

questions.question: What does Paul say they do when they are reviled or persecuted in 1 Corinthians 4:12?
questions.correctAnswer: They bless and suffer it
questions.explanation: 1 Corinthians 4:12 says that when reviled, Paul and his companions bless, and when persecuted, they endure it.

questions.question: True or False: According to 1 Corinthians 4:16, Paul urges the Corinthians to be followers of him.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: 1 Corinthians 4:16 shows Paul beseeching the Corinthians to be followers of him as he follows Christ.

questions.question: Who did Paul send to the Corinthians to remind them of his ways, according to 1 Corinthians 4:17?
questions.correctAnswer: Timotheus
questions.explanation: 1 Corinthians 4:17 says Paul sent Timotheus, his beloved and faithful son in the Lord, to remind the Corinthians of his ways in Christ.

questions.question: According to 1 Corinthians 4:20, what is not the kingdom of God?
questions.correctAnswer: In word
questions.explanation: 1 Corinthians 4:20 states that the kingdom of God is not in word, but in power.

questions.question: True or False: In 1 Corinthians 4:3, Paul says it is important to be judged by man's judgment.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: 1 Corinthians 4:3 shows Paul saying it is a small thing to be judged by man’s judgment and that he does not judge himself.

questions.question: Fill in the blank from 1 Corinthians 4:14: 'I write not these things to shame you, but as my beloved ______ I warn you.'
questions.correctAnswer: sons
questions.explanation: 1 Corinthians 4:14 uses the phrase 'my beloved sons' indicating a close and caring relationship.

questions.question: What question does Paul ask in 1 Corinthians 4:7 regarding who makes one differ from another?
options: Who maketh thee to differ from another?
Who is greater than the other?
questions.correctAnswer: Who maketh thee to differ from another?
questions.explanation: 1 Corinthians 4:7 asks rhetorically who makes a person differ from another to emphasize humility.

questions.question: True or False: According to 1 Corinthians 4:19, Paul will come to the Corinthians shortly, if the Lord wills.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: 1 Corinthians 4:19 confirms Paul’s intention to come shortly to the Corinthians, if it is the Lord’s will.

medium.title: 1 Corinthians Chapter 4 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from 1 Corinthians Chapter 4 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is struggling with pride and comparing themselves to others. Based on 1 Corinthians 4, what biblical truth would you share about humility?
options: God is the one who makes us differ and all we have is received from Him
We should boast about our own accomplishments
Comparing ourselves to others is a sign of spiritual maturity
Pride is acceptable if it encourages others
questions.correctAnswer: God is the one who makes us differ and all we have is received from Him
questions.explanation: 1 Corinthians 4:7 teaches that no one should boast as if they had not received what they have, because God is the one who makes us different. This encourages humility and gratitude.

questions.question: How does 1 Corinthians 4 teach about faithfulness in service to God?
options: Stewards must be found faithful in their responsibilities
Faithfulness is optional if one feels tired
Only leaders need to be faithful
Faithfulness is less important than being popular
questions.correctAnswer: Stewards must be found faithful in their responsibilities
questions.explanation: 1 Corinthians 4:2 states that it is required of stewards to be found faithful, highlighting the importance of trustworthiness and faithfulness in serving God.

questions.question: A believer feels judged harshly by others and wonders how to handle it. What counsel does 1 Corinthians 4 offer?
options: God is the ultimate judge, not human opinions
We should always seek to please people first
Avoid all criticism by hiding your faith
questions.correctAnswer: God is the ultimate judge, not human opinions
questions.explanation: 1 Corinthians 4:3-4 explains that human judgment is minor and the Lord is the one who judges, so believers should trust God's judgment rather than worry about others' opinions.

questions.question: What does 1 Corinthians 4 teach about the timing of judgment and accountability?
options: Do not judge before the Lord comes to reveal all things
Judge others quickly to correct them
Judgment should be based on appearances
questions.correctAnswer: Do not judge before the Lord comes to reveal all things
questions.explanation: 1 Corinthians 4:5 instructs believers to withhold judgment until the Lord comes and reveals hidden things, emphasizing patience and trust in God's timing.

questions.question: A believer is tempted to become boastful about their spiritual gifts. How does 1 Corinthians 4 advise them?
options: Do not think of men above what is written to avoid pride
Boast as much as possible to encourage others
Ignore humility and focus on gifts
Compete with others to show superiority
questions.correctAnswer: Do not think of men above what is written to avoid pride
questions.explanation: 1 Corinthians 4:6 warns against thinking of men above what is written, urging believers to be humble and avoid becoming puffed up against one another.

questions.question: How does 1 Corinthians 4 describe the apostles' experience in relation to worldly status?
options: They are made a spectacle and treated as the last, appointed to death
questions.correctAnswer: They are made a spectacle and treated as the last, appointed to death
questions.explanation: 1 Corinthians 4:9 describes the apostles as being set forth as last and appointed to death, made spectacles to the world, angels, and men, showing their suffering and humility.

questions.question: What attitude toward suffering and persecution does 1 Corinthians 4 recommend for believers?
options: Bless those who revile and suffer persecution patiently
Retaliate against those who persecute you
Ignore persecution and pretend it doesn't exist
questions.correctAnswer: Bless those who revile and suffer persecution patiently
questions.explanation: 1 Corinthians 4:12 teaches that when reviled, believers should bless; when persecuted, they should endure it, exemplifying Christlike patience and love.

questions.question: Based on 1 Corinthians 4, how should a Christian respond to being defamed or considered worthless?
options: Endure it as being made the filth of the world and offscouring of all things
questions.correctAnswer: Endure it as being made the filth of the world and offscouring of all things
questions.explanation: 1 Corinthians 4:13 describes apostles as being treated as the filth and offscouring of the world, encouraging believers to endure such treatment humbly for Christ’s sake.

questions.question: How does Paul describe his relationship with the Corinthian believers in 1 Corinthians 4?
options: As a spiritual father who has begotten them through the gospel
As a distant teacher with no personal connection
As an equal peer with no authority
As a critic who condemns them
questions.correctAnswer: As a spiritual father who has begotten them through the gospel
questions.explanation: 1 Corinthians 4:14-15 shows Paul referring to the believers as his beloved sons and himself as their spiritual father, emphasizing care and responsibility.

questions.question: What practical advice does Paul give to the Corinthians about following leadership based on 1 Corinthians 4?
options: Be followers of Paul as he follows Christ
Follow only those who are popular
questions.correctAnswer: Be followers of Paul as he follows Christ
questions.explanation: 1 Corinthians 4:16 encourages believers to be followers of Paul as he is a follower of Christ, highlighting the importance of following godly examples.

questions.question: What does 1 Corinthians 4 teach about boasting and spiritual maturity?
options: Boasting leads to division and should be avoided
Boasting is a sign of spiritual strength
Boast about your talents to gain respect
questions.correctAnswer: Boasting leads to division and should be avoided
questions.explanation: 1 Corinthians 4:6 warns against being puffed up or boasting one against another, teaching humility to maintain unity in the church.

questions.question: True or False: According to 1 Corinthians 4, the kingdom of God is shown primarily through powerful words rather than power.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: 1 Corinthians 4:20 states that the kingdom of God is not in word, but in power, emphasizing that true Christian life is demonstrated through God’s power, not just speech.

questions.question: True or False: Paul expresses a desire to come to the Corinthians soon to display authority in meekness or discipline if necessary.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: 1 Corinthians 4:21 shows Paul asking whether he should come with a rod or in love and meekness, indicating his readiness to discipline or encourage as needed.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Paul sent Timotheus to the Corinthians because he is his _______ son and faithful in the Lord.
questions.correctAnswer: beloved
questions.explanation: 1 Corinthians 4:17 refers to Timotheus as Paul's beloved son and faithful in the Lord, sent to remind the Corinthians of Paul's ways in Christ.

questions.question: How does 1 Corinthians 4 encourage believers to handle divisions and selfish ambition within the church?
options: Learn from apostles not to think beyond what is written and avoid pride
Compete for superiority to prove who is better
Ignore conflicts and allow divisions to grow
Boast in your own wisdom and reject others
questions.correctAnswer: Learn from apostles not to think beyond what is written and avoid pride
questions.explanation: 1 Corinthians 4:6 teaches believers to avoid arrogance and divisions by following the example of apostles and the Word, fostering humility and unity.

hard.title: 1 Corinthians Chapter 4 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from 1 Corinthians Chapter 4.

questions.question: According to 1 Corinthians 4:1, Paul describes apostles as ministers of Christ and what else?
options: Stewards of the mysteries of God
questions.correctAnswer: Stewards of the mysteries of God
questions.explanation: 1 Corinthians 4:1 states that apostles are to be regarded as 'ministers of Christ, and stewards of the mysteries of God,' emphasizing their role as entrusted managers of divine truths.

questions.question: What is required of a steward according to 1 Corinthians 4:2?
questions.correctAnswer: Faithfulness
questions.explanation: Verse 2 highlights that a steward must be found faithful, underscoring the importance of trustworthiness in handling God's mysteries.

questions.question: In 1 Corinthians 4:3-4, Paul says he does not judge himself but mentions who as the true judge?
questions.correctAnswer: The Lord
questions.explanation: Paul states that he does not judge himself but recognizes the Lord as the one who judges him (1 Corinthians 4:4), showing reliance on divine rather than human judgment.

questions.question: What does Paul urge the Corinthians not to do before the time, as stated in 1 Corinthians 4:5?
questions.correctAnswer: Judge anything
questions.explanation: Verse 5 advises believers to withhold judgment until the Lord comes, who will reveal hidden things and judge rightly.

questions.question: In 1 Corinthians 4:6, Paul uses himself and Apollos as examples to teach what lesson?
options: Not to think beyond what is written
questions.correctAnswer: Not to think beyond what is written
questions.explanation: Paul uses himself and Apollos figuratively to teach the Corinthians not to be arrogant or elevate men above Scripture (1 Corinthians 4:6).

questions.question: According to 1 Corinthians 4:7, why should no one boast as if they had not received what they have?
options: Because all things are received from God
Because humility is the only virtue
questions.correctAnswer: Because all things are received from God
questions.explanation: Paul reminds that any difference or gift a person has is received, so boasting as if it was earned independently is inappropriate (1 Corinthians 4:7).

questions.question: In 1 Corinthians 4:8, Paul addresses the Corinthians' attitude by stating they are full and rich and have reigned as what?
questions.correctAnswer: Kings without us
questions.explanation: Paul sarcastically says the Corinthians act as if they reign as kings without the apostles, encouraging humility and recognition of apostolic authority (1 Corinthians 4:8).

questions.question: What does Paul say about the apostles' status in the world in 1 Corinthians 4:9?
options: They are set forth as last, appointed to death, and made spectacles
questions.correctAnswer: They are set forth as last, appointed to death, and made spectacles
questions.explanation: Verse 9 describes apostles as being presented as the last, facing death, and made a spectacle before the world, angels, and men, illustrating their suffering and humiliation.

questions.question: In 1 Corinthians 4:10, Paul contrasts the apostles with the Corinthians by saying the apostles are fools and weak, while the Corinthians are what?
questions.correctAnswer: Wise and strong
questions.explanation: Paul contrasts the apostles' apparent foolishness and weakness with the Corinthians' wisdom and strength, highlighting irony and spiritual attitude differences (1 Corinthians 4:10).

questions.question: Which hardships does Paul mention that the apostles endure up to the present hour in 1 Corinthians 4:11?
options: Hunger, thirst, nakedness, being buffeted, and having no certain dwelling place
questions.correctAnswer: Hunger, thirst, nakedness, being buffeted, and having no certain dwelling place
questions.explanation: Paul lists these specific hardships to emphasize the apostles' suffering and contrast with the Corinthians' comfortable state (1 Corinthians 4:11).

questions.question: In 1 Corinthians 4:12, how do the apostles respond when they are reviled and persecuted?
questions.correctAnswer: They bless and suffer it
questions.explanation: Paul highlights the apostles' humility and endurance by stating they bless when reviled and suffer persecution patiently (1 Corinthians 4:12).

questions.question: True or False: According to 1 Corinthians 4:14, Paul writes to shame the Corinthians for their behavior.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Paul explicitly states in 1 Corinthians 4:14 that he does not write to shame them but to warn them as beloved sons, showing pastoral concern.

questions.question: Who does Paul describe as his 'beloved son' and faithful in the Lord in 1 Corinthians 4:17?
questions.correctAnswer: Timotheus
questions.explanation: Paul sends Timotheus to remind the Corinthians of Paul's ways in Christ, calling him his beloved son and faithful servant (1 Corinthians 4:17).

questions.question: According to 1 Corinthians 4:19-20, what does Paul say the kingdom of God is not and what is it?
options: Not in word, but in power
Not in wealth, but in wisdom
Not in law, but in grace
Not in speech, but in knowledge
questions.correctAnswer: Not in word, but in power
questions.explanation: Paul emphasizes that the kingdom of God is demonstrated by power, not merely by words, highlighting the importance of spiritual efficacy (1 Corinthians 4:20).

questions.question: What two approaches does Paul ask the Corinthians to consider in 1 Corinthians 4:21 when he comes to them?
options: With a rod, or in love and in the spirit of meekness
questions.correctAnswer: With a rod, or in love and in the spirit of meekness
questions.explanation: Paul presents a rhetorical question contrasting disciplinary authority ('a rod') with gentle love and meekness, inviting the Corinthians to choose their response (1 Corinthians 4:21).

theological.title: 1 Corinthians Chapter 4 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from 1 Corinthians Chapter 4 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: According to 1 Corinthians 4:1, how should believers regard the apostles?
options: As ministers of Christ and stewards of the mysteries of God
questions.correctAnswer: As ministers of Christ and stewards of the mysteries of God
questions.explanation: 1 Corinthians 4:1 describes apostles as ministers of Christ and stewards of God's mysteries, emphasizing their role as faithful managers of divine revelation, consistent with stewardship themes in Luke 12:42 and faithful service in Ephesians 3:7.

questions.question: What is required of stewards according to 1 Corinthians 4:2?
questions.correctAnswer: To be found faithful
questions.explanation: 1 Corinthians 4:2 states that stewards must be found faithful, highlighting the essential Christian virtue of faithfulness, echoed in Luke 16:10 and 1 Peter 4:10 regarding stewardship and responsibility.

questions.question: What does Paul say about judging himself in 1 Corinthians 4:3?
options: He judges himself better than others
questions.correctAnswer: He does not judge himself
questions.explanation: Paul expresses in 1 Corinthians 4:3 that he does not judge himself, showing humility and reliance on God's judgment, which aligns with Jesus' teaching in John 12:47 and James 4:12 about the ultimate divine judgment.

questions.question: Who is the ultimate judge of Paul, as stated in 1 Corinthians 4:4?
questions.correctAnswer: The Lord
questions.explanation: 1 Corinthians 4:4 clarifies that the Lord is the one who judges Paul, reinforcing the biblical doctrine of God's sovereignty in judgment as seen in Romans 14:10 and Hebrews 4:13.

questions.question: What does 1 Corinthians 4:5 encourage believers to do regarding judgment?
questions.correctAnswer: Judge nothing before the time
questions.explanation: The verse instructs believers to withhold judgment until the Lord returns to reveal all things, consistent with Jesus' teaching in Matthew 7:1-2 and the eschatological judgment in Revelation 20:12.

questions.question: Why did Paul use himself and Apollos as examples in 1 Corinthians 4:6?
options: To prevent believers from being arrogant about men
To establish hierarchy in the church
questions.correctAnswer: To prevent believers from being arrogant about men
questions.explanation: Paul uses himself and Apollos figuratively to teach humility and avoid pride, as 1 Corinthians 4:6 says, which corresponds with Proverbs 27:2 and James 4:6 emphasizing humility.

questions.question: What question does Paul ask in 1 Corinthians 4:7 to challenge boasting?
options: Who makes you differ from another?
Why do you not work harder?
questions.correctAnswer: Who makes you differ from another?
questions.explanation: Paul's rhetorical question in 1 Corinthians 4:7 challenges believers to recognize that all gifts come from God, discouraging boasting, which harmonizes with James 1:17 and 1 Corinthians 12:4-6 on spiritual gifts as God-given.

questions.question: In 1 Corinthians 4:8, what does Paul say some Corinthians thought they were?
options: Full, rich, and reigning as kings
questions.correctAnswer: Full, rich, and reigning as kings
questions.explanation: Paul rebukes the Corinthians in 1 Corinthians 4:8 for their arrogance, claiming they saw themselves as already reigning, which contrasts with the apostolic experience of suffering, parallel to James 2:5 and Psalm 49:16.

questions.question: According to 1 Corinthians 4:9, how does Paul describe the apostles' position in God's plan?
options: Set forth last, as appointed to death
questions.correctAnswer: Set forth last, as appointed to death
questions.explanation: Paul depicts apostles as last and facing death in 1 Corinthians 4:9, highlighting their suffering and witness role, consistent with Jesus' prediction in Mark 10:39 and the suffering servant motif in Isaiah 53.

questions.question: What contrasts does Paul make between apostles and Corinthians in 1 Corinthians 4:10?
options: Apostles are fools and weak; Corinthians are wise and strong
Apostles are rich and powerful; Corinthians are poor
Apostles are honored; Corinthians are despised
Apostles are silent; Corinthians speak loudly
questions.correctAnswer: Apostles are fools and weak; Corinthians are wise and strong
questions.explanation: Paul contrasts the apostles as fools and weak with the Corinthians as wise and strong in 1 Corinthians 4:10 to expose worldly values, aligning with 2 Corinthians 12:10 and Matthew 5:3 about divine strength in weakness.

questions.question: Which hardships do Paul and his companions endure as described in 1 Corinthians 4:11-12?
options: Hunger, thirst, nakedness, persecution, and labor
questions.correctAnswer: Hunger, thirst, nakedness, persecution, and labor
questions.explanation: Paul describes suffering hunger, thirst, nakedness, persecution, and labor in 1 Corinthians 4:11-12, reflecting the apostolic hardship theme found in 2 Corinthians 11:27 and Hebrews 11:37.

questions.question: How does Paul describe the apostles' reputation in 1 Corinthians 4:13?
options: As the filth of the world and offscouring of all things
questions.correctAnswer: As the filth of the world and offscouring of all things
questions.explanation: Paul states in 1 Corinthians 4:13 that apostles are despised as filth and offscouring, illustrating the cost of faithful witness, consistent with Psalm 22:6 and Philippians 3:8.

questions.question: Why does Paul write to the Corinthians in 1 Corinthians 4:14?
options: To warn them as beloved sons, not to shame them
questions.correctAnswer: To warn them as beloved sons, not to shame them
questions.explanation: Paul writes in 1 Corinthians 4:14 to warn the Corinthians as beloved sons, showing pastoral care and discipline, mirroring Hebrews 12:6 and Proverbs 3:12 about God’s loving correction.

questions.question: Who does Paul refer to as his 'beloved son' and faithful in the Lord in 1 Corinthians 4:17?
questions.correctAnswer: Timotheus
questions.explanation: Paul identifies Timotheus as his beloved and faithful son in 1 Corinthians 4:17, highlighting mentorship and apostolic succession, consistent with 2 Timothy 1:2 and Philippians 2:22.

questions.question: What does Paul say about the kingdom of God in 1 Corinthians 4:20?
options: It is not in word, but in power
It is established by speech alone
questions.correctAnswer: It is not in word, but in power
questions.explanation: Paul affirms in 1 Corinthians 4:20 that the kingdom of God is demonstrated by power, not mere words, which is echoed in Romans 1:16 and Acts 1:8 emphasizing the Spirit’s power.
